title: Axing payroll tax and raising GST is the right economic tonic
text:
Outside Canberra, the book struck a nerve with those concerned with the limitations of Canberra’s gradual but persistent consolidation of fiscal power and influence.

The federalist theme of the book was given some air under John Howard and the Coalition’s introduction of the GST in 2000, giving states and territories access to a broad-based consumption tax and going some way to restoring their financial independence.

Payroll tax is universally regarded as a drag on economic activity.

The key message in Rebuilding the Federation was that opportunities for greater political and economic autonomy in Australia’s federation were being overlooked at a time when reform could be used to improve the nation’s economic performance.

This message is as relevant today as it was 25 years ago.

At a time when the economy is facing significant headwinds, evidence demonstrates that a better functioning federation could deliver immediate results for reviving household spending, boosting wages growth, and driving employment.

In a 2007 report for the Council for the Australian Federation, Professors Anne Twomey and Glenn Withers identified that “federations have consistently out-performed unitary states in economic terms”.

The research also showed that “federalism may have increased Australia’s prosperity by $4507 per head in 2006 and that this amount could be increased by another $4188 or even more if Australia’s federal system were more financially decentralised”.

These lessons have not been lost on our present-day economic managers.

When Commonwealth, state and territory treasurers departed the Council on Federal Financial Relations this month, agreement was reached to focus on reform initiatives outlined in the 2017 Productivity Commission’s Shifting the Dial report.

The Productivity Commission report is the first of its kind, identifying “factors and influencers” that will determine Australia’s economic performance over the medium term.

Microeconomic garbage

The report noted that the economy had “performed very well” over a long period but said “it’s time to take out the microeconomic garbage” and that tax reform “must not be considered dead”.

Over the past decade, state payroll tax collections have increased by 45 per cent from $16.8 billion in 2008-09 to almost $24.4 billion in 2017-18. Payroll tax is universally regarded as a drag on economic activity and is ultimately paid by employees through lower wages and higher prices for consumers.

Abolishing this tax would remove a huge burden from our economy, put more people into work, and deliver higher productivity.

The idea was first given an airing in the 2010 Henry Tax Review, which recommended that “state payroll taxes should eventually be replaced with revenue from more efficient broad-based taxes”. Compensating state and territories for lost revenue could be achieved by broadening the GST or by a modest (but politically courageous) lift in the GST from 10 to 12.5 per cent.

Advertisement

This month, we witnessed the federalist revival envisioned in Rebuilding the Federation when NSW Treasurer Dominic Perrottet announced that the state wanted to “drive a national vision for the federation that encourages innovation and competition”.

When the state and territory treasurers next meet Treasurer Josh Frydenberg, they could abandon their calls for an increase in infrastructure spending and Newstart, and instead stand united in a call for tax reform, which starts with the removal of payroll taxes in exchange for a broader-based consumption tax.
description: Federalism helps increase Australia's productivity. Swapping the payroll tax for GST reform would make it work even better.
